item.description: Competition in popular Olympic activities is incorporated in this exciting game using decimals from 10ths to 1000ths. Over 40 problems using addition, subtraction, multiplication, and division of decimals are included. Olympic activities including the javelin, discus, shot-put, and pole vault allow students to earn points toward winning a gold, silver, or bronze medal. For 2-4 players plus a referee.

Over 400 problems for each of the four basic math operations are included in this exciting fractions game. Competition in ten popular Olympics events are used to motivate players. For example, the javelin, discus, shot-put, pole vault, and many more activities allow students to earn points towards winning a gold, silver, or bronze medal. For 2-4 players and a referee.

Two players or teams can score touchdowns, field goals, and experience other activities found in football games as they practice multiplication skills. For example: 6X2 = 12 which represents a fumble with no points scored.

Players will begin to understand the problem solving details that go into having a party as they play this game. Included are activities that use addition and subtraction of time, money, and liquid measurement. For example: 4 cups of punch equal one quart. How many cups of punch equal one gallon? The time is 1:00p.m. and the party starts in 15 minutes. What time does the party start? 2-4 players Grades 2-6

Students become masterminds as they use inductive and deductive reasoning with this exciting game. Using colorful bears, students build color pattern riddles that their opponent must solve on the transparent gameboard. This activity is great for whole class competition or for use in learning centers. 2- players or whole class participation. Grades 1-6

Here's an action packed board game designed to meet a variety of educational needs while tapping into America's favorite pastime... Baseball! As players build their own teams, they use their own baseball cards or the baseball cards included in the game to answer problem solving questions. Included are integrated reading, math, and geography skills covering time zones, states and capitals, major league cities, rivers, lakes, and oceans. Lots of baseball trivia is included. There are five levels of difficulty, allowing players of different ability levels to play together. 2-4 players or teams. Grades 2-12

Play golf while you learn to compute combinations of addition, subtraction, multiplication, division, cubes, square roots, and more. Using 60 cards in the deck along with golf terminology, players draw "stroke" cards to create equations which solve a target number. After nine rounds of play the game is over and the player with the lowest score wins the game.

45 durable dominoes are included in this challenging game. It may be played at three levels of difficulty, covering hours, half hours, and quarter hours using clock faces, digital time, and written time. 1-4 players. Grades 2-6

The object of the game is to advance all of your stakes to the finish line before your opponent in order to win. The game can be played opposite each other or side-by-side. When playing opposite each other, the game cards must be placed in the card bay so that the green block is at the bottom and at the player’s right. Playing side-by-side, both cards must be placed with the green block at the bottom. Stakes must be advanced vertically only. There are three (3) versions to this game: RANDOM, MIX, and FIX. Random is the basic version and should be learned first....

Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in either the ones, tens, hundreds and thousands place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board. Grades 1-4

From the Steve Jackson Games website:

Marriage. Royalty. Tragedy. Will your line reign supreme? King's Blood is a fast-paced multi-player card game. Build the family tree by arranging marriages, exiling rivals, and crowning new royalty. Match a character with a compatible member of the opposite sex, and start a new generation. Play the last family member from your hand, and you've won!

King's Blood was originally published by Kadokawa Shoten in Japan, where it remains a fan favorite. Steve Jackson Games is proud to offer the authorized English translation of this fast, fun game, complete with all the beautiful original manga artwork.

90 cards in a tuck box.

item.description: Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in the thousand, millions, up to the hundred millions place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board.

Here's a great, competitive, fun-filled game. Each player chooses a colored pawn and follows the track around the board by spinning and moving to a specific number in either the tenths, hundredths, and thousandths place. The winner is decided by the first player who makes it once around the board and follows their colored alley to the center of the board. Grades 4-7

This started life as a computer game by Ingo Althöfer and has been worked into a board game by Reinhold Wittig. The board is in the shape of Easter Island (Rapa Nui) and has 45 spaces. Each player has 2 pieces which are placed on the board. On a turn a piece is moved to an adjacent empty space and a wooden die-holder is then put in the place just moved from. A die is then rolled and put in the holder. After the first 9 moves, each turn also has a second element. This is to remove an empty holder from the board or to roll a die and remove a die from the board with the same number (thus leaving an empty holder). The aim is to be the last player to be able to move.
You need to be able to corner off an area for yourself and also to be in positions where removal of dice will benefit your future movement.

This uses a similar idea to the popular 'parking' puzzles but in a strategy game. Each player has 5 vehicles - 3 normal cars (2x1 spaces), a bus (3x1 spaces) and a Smart car (1x1). On your turn you have 3 choices: 1) Place a vehicle face down, 2) Turn one of your vehicles face up and choose its direction of travel without altering its position (so the larger vehicles can choose two directions, the Smart can choose four), 3) Move one of your vehicles one space in its direction of travel. 
The aim is to be the last player to be able to move. Even if one cannot move at some stage of the game if your way is subsequently cleared you can still move then.

This is a collection of 12 games playable with the same components released to commemorate the 150th anniversary of Gauss' death. The games are mainly 2 player. They use a set of wooden blocks which come in lengths of 1 to 6. A die is used in many of them to determine the length of the piece to be placed. There are variants on connecting-sides-of-the-board, placement-within-a-limited-space, moving- across-the-board, blocking and capturing games. 8 are adult games, 4 children's games. There are also an additional 2 adult games by Peter Lewe.

Over 400 real-life challenges are included in this great game. Players learn to purchase furniture, clothing, appliances and more. Extensive drill in computing percentages, fractional discounts, keeping financial records and reconciling accounts is covered. Great for home use, and learning centers. 2-4 Players Grades 5-12

name.value: A la caza de la gelatina
La caccia al budino di gelatina

item.description:
In the center of the board, there are wobble puddings in a clearing. Players roll a die and move their 'little monster' to collect them and bring them back to their home. But the puddings are guarded by a dragon, which may be moved when the players roll its symbol. Players can be send home like in pachisi, with the capturing player also capturing the pudding.

The game ends when all 10 puddings are distributed. They have 1-3 points on the bottom side, and the player with the highest total wins.

A description from Greg Costikyan:

Aki Jarvinen has posted cards and rules for GameGame 1.0… which he pitches as an attempt to do for games what Understanding Comics does for comics: that is, to provide insight into the nature of games in a game, in the same what that Understanding is both “about comics” and a comic.

Thus, his cards are things like “Goal” and “Environment” and “Victory/End Condition.” There’s both a coherent set of rules for determining victory and a roleplaying element: players must improvise what the game they are creating is like, e.g., describing what their “Victory/End Condition” is–but they can only have one if they have the relevant card.

Version 2.0 recently became available at the website below.

Website: http://gamegame.blogs.com/

item.description: In Henne Berta (Hen Berta in English) the player feeds a hen with grain and in return gathers eggs to a little basket. The first player that gets 3 eggs to basket is the winner. The game contains a wooden board, large wooden pieces and little baskets for every player.
RPM is a race simulation released by Grow during the 80's in Brazil.

How long did John Glenn orbit the earth? This and many more curious questions are included in this fun-filled game. History, math, problem solving, and trivia are incorporated into three levels of difficulty so that students at different ability levels can be challenged as they play together. 2-4 Players Grade 3-8

Place Search is a great activity in a four-sided domino format. Players match words with their corresponding numerals. Two levels of difficulty cover numbers through the thousands place. 1-4 players. Grades 3-12

Place Search is a great activity in a four-sided domino format. Players match words with their corresponding numerals. Two levels of difficulty cover numbers through the hundred millions place. 1-4 players. Grades 3-12
Using the tic-tac-toe format and three levels of difficulty, students are immersed in competitive drill with equivalent fractions.
This game contains 45 dominoes and five game ideas using halves, thirds, fourths, fifths, sixths, and eighths. It's great for home use or learning centers.

Most likely the first "real" wargame (by today's standards) released in Brazil, it had lukewarm reception during the 80's and has been discontinued. 
The game simulates a battle between two fictitious armies, using an hexagonal board and two sets of rules: basic and advanced.
This is the same Avalon Hill's Tactics II (1958), with a redesigned hexgrid mapboard.

item.description:
"Jon Compton's tactical hex and counter game of WWII combat. This set focuses on Germany versus Poland at the start of the war."

Each hex on the map represents an area approximately 100 yards across. Each playing piece represents about 40-60 men (a platoon) or half a dozen vehicles or towed weapons . . . For ease of play, the game scales are approximated. Time is also abstracted, thus turns represent several minutes.

The FOXHOLE system is simple to learn and fast playing that focuses on the invasion of Poland. Its a good diversion from the more heavy fair of historical board-wargaming.

FOXHOLE SET 2 includes:
-Ten new scenarios, six exclusively with this set, and four incorporating elements from Set 1.
-Twenty-four unit cards
-Over one hundred playing pieces -Tactical Battles Map A - and One rule book

Approx. translation of the box.
 Card game in the universe of "Sillage". The comic of Philippe Buchet and Jean David Morvan.

The Sillage convoy explores space trying to find worlds to colonize while looking for aliens species that are in danger of extinction. In this game you create a Sillage Ops and, with action cards, you try to install aliens on different planets.
Be careful, the competition is rough : the other players can play "poukram" (NB : favorite swear of the heroin) to make your task more difficult.

item.description: This game is played on a hex board, you have 3 Figures, the first (King) can move only 1 step (if you lose that piece you are out of the game), the second piece can move 2 step and the third can move 3 step. When you move on a hex a stone fall, so the hex is no more usable. When you must move one figure on an empty hex, the first time you can turn over the figure, the second time the figure goes out of the game. If is the King all your figures go out. The last player on the board is the winner.

Incorporate baseball with addition, subtraction, multiplication and division problems. With three levels of difficulty, students from first to sixth grade can have fun in pairs or small groups as the play baseball. Get the whole class involved by creating an overhead transparency from the black line master that is included. This game may also be adapted for weekly homework assignments and remedial math programs. 2-4 players or 2 teams.

It's the first game of a trilogy of two-player Napoleonic campaign games.
Napoleon's Italian campaigns take place during the time of Napoleon's campaigns from 1796 through 1800 in Italy.
The game contains the maps, 252 counters, charts and tables
Players journey around the Roman Empire, conquering garrison forts in a race to proclaimed "Caesar"! The fascinating history of the Roman Empire will be explored whilst playing the game!

item.description: Picdoku is a brand new pictorial version of the Sudoku craze that has gripped us all! It can be played individually or competitively by 2 players or teams. Each game includes 182 sturdy re-usable tokens and 30 double-sided playing boards so that 60 different games can be played again and again.

Using 45 dominoes, players may play at 1of 3 levels of difficulty while adding fractions to find the sum of 1. Fractional parts are shown in pictorial and numerical form. It's a great activity for home and in learning centers.
Santiago 1898: Final del Imperio is a simulation of the campaign of Santiago de Cuba during the Spanish - American War.

Introduce children to the great American pastime...BASEBALL while they practice multiplication problems with factors of 3,4,6,7,8, and 9. Multiplication problems determine base hits, singles, triples, home runs, and more. Example: 3X7 = 21 which denotes a single. 4X9 = 36 or a "triple". 2 players or teams may play. Grades 4-8
Battle of Lake Trasimene (217 BC) during the Second Punic war.
"Expedition of the Thousand": Garibaldi's campaign against the Kingdom of Two Sicilies.
Battle of Adowa : Italy against the Abyssina.

Two sets of 30 quadromino tiles provide drill in equivalent fraction recognition at two levels of difficulty. Level 1 includes fractions from 1/4 to 10/12; Level 2 covers 1/4 to 21/24. Each tile shows fractions in numerical form. It's a great activity for individuals, play at home, or in learning centers.

Uses the same game system as Invasion of Italy, Red Parachutes and Red Steel. As far as we know, this is the first detailed treatment of the battles that, at last, stopped Erwin Rommel’s attempts to take the British position in the Nile delta. They also established Bernard Montgomery as the British general finally able to defeat the "Desert Fox."

Following the fall of Tobruk in May 1942, the Commonwealth forces in the desert struggled to reach the last real defensive position before Alexandria and halt what seemed to be an unstoppable Afrika Korps. At battalion and company level, four turns a day and 2 kilometers per hex, this game includes German, Italian, Indian, British, South African, New Zealand, Australian, Free French and Greek units that fought in the desperate struggle.

Scenarios include the Australian and South African spoiling attack in mid-July, the late June battle for the Mersa Matruh position where slow response almost cost the Commonwealth the bulk of the New Zealand Division, the first Axis attack on the Alamein line in early July, the last Axis attack to break the Allied line at Alam el Halfa at the end of August, Operation LIGHTFOOT: the Eighth Army’s attack against the Axis line in late October and the massive campaign from the end of June to the beginning of November 1942.

Four full-sized maps and 2,100 game pieces.

item.description:
Using the same game system as MacArthur's Return, Blood on the Snow and Winter Fury, this game covers the fighting in southern Malaya as the advancing Japanese drive the British, Indian and Australian forces back on their base at Singapore. What is different about this game is that it allows the British player to request the 7th Australian Infantry Division and 7th Armored Brigade, historically at sea during the battle and considered as a possible remedy. These two powerful formations might just turn the tide and defeat the Japanese.

Can the British player hold on long and well enough to convince General Wavell that the situation can be restored? Can the Japanese player out-manuever and outfight the British forces defending Johore province and gain a toehold on the island before resistance stiffens or reinforcements arrive?

One full-sized map, 420 game pieces.

name.value: So You Think You Know Maine

item.description:
From the box:
"A game of Maine trivia suitable for natives and people from away."

Players start in Kittery (Southern Maine). Counties in Maine represent different categories. As players roll and move around the board, they must collect cards at each county seat. Players then race to Fort Kent (Northern Maine) to win the game.

Overlord is a "2 player game of pure 3D strategy".

The game is played on a 7x9 board with a crenellated wall located on the middle row between the two players. Both players have 14 pieces located in the back 2 rows on each side of the wall and attempt to capture the opponents pieces by landing on top of them. Pieces move and stack in various ways, and the game is won when one player is reduced to a single stack.

item.description: Three levels of difficulty are included in this fast-paced tic-tac-toe styled game. Three game cards are included and players match antonyms from their playing card, to base words found on the spinner. The first person to form a line of antonyms on the board wins the game.

The year is 2340. Just as in all of history, conquest is at the heart of mankind. Enslave or become a slave is the future. You are in charge of breaking through the wall of your enemy’s city to allow the entry of your battalion to take over. Organic Titazium metal (O37T2y) has been used in the construction of all walls during this time period, which makes them virtually impenetrable. The wall cubes must be removed carefully or the wall structure will collapse and repair itself thus defeating your mission. While you are attacking the walls of your enemy, they in turn are attacking you. By using limited means, you must minimize the damage directed to your city. Victory belongs to he who enters the city first.

This is a very large book (900 pages) explaining rules to all kinds of games. The first 300 pages are dedicated solely to card games. The book then moves on to traditional board and dice games such as checkers, backgammon, and craps. There are many word and guessing games. Outdoor activities are also listed, including races, snow or water games, lawn games, and full-blown sports.

Ideas for adults' get-togethers include quick-thinking contests and even dancing games. The book details countless games for children, suitable for everyday play or social events such as birthday parties. Some of the party games are geared toward specific holidays.

This huge volume devotes one little paragraph to branded games such as Monopoly, Pit, and Flinch. It only mentions that they exist, and require special equipment, which is purchased along with the rules.

Although you'll find very familiar entries such as bridge, marbles, and baseball, many of the games are less known, or a variation on a more familiar idea. Some of the names are intriguing in their own right. Here's a sampling of names of the many games to learn:

Misery Nap
Bierspiel
Anti-nudist
Hearts of Lettuce
Skeegee-Weegee
The G Man Never Takes His Ease
Literary Salad
Strawberries Without Cream
Schnozzle Race

In Hey, Bartender! everyone is trying to take change from a friendly bartender. Each player is dealt a hand of seven cards. The 'bartender' also gets seven cards, played face up on the table. The object of the game is to trade cards with the bartender, making change such that the bartender gives the player more points than the player gives the bartender. Play continues until all players have exhausted their hands, at which time the player with the most points wins.

Hey, Bartender! was designed as another version of Pennywise played with cards, and was published in Game Trade Monthly in 2000.

Players learn how to build words using suffixes and base words. The base words are located within the gameboard squares, and the suffixes are listed on the spinner. Students spin and move to the first space where that suffix can be used with a base word to form a word. 245 words can be formed.

Wolf im Schafspelz (Wolf in Sheep's Clothing) is a deduction game, wherein players take turns trying to pick the wolf out from a flock of sheep using sheepdogs. For those desiring a more complex game, trees are included to break up the sheepdogs' lines of sight.

name.value: Alternative Games for Those Who Like a Challenge

item.description:
From the back cover:

"The alternative games in this booklet are all designed to be played with standard equipment. They offer exciting new dimensions to games played on or with draught boards, cards, dominoes etc., helping to eliminate the constant financial burden of purchasing expensive and often short-lived new games.

The games in Alternative Games for Those Who Like a Challenge are based on popular games that have been modified so they are even more competitive and exciting.
At the same time, they are easy to learn if you already know the standard edition, providing hours of inexpensive entertainment, making this booklet desirable for most game lovers.

Other books designed by Tony Crow are:
Alternative Games for the Family and
Alternative Games for the Studious"

This book contains rules for modified card games, draught board games, Scrabble games and billiard table games.

Black Abyss is a space civilization game where players explore the galaxy for habitable planets and then scan the planets surface for beneficial terrain. Players will expand their empire by colonizing these planets and erecting buildings that best use the terrain and available space of each planet. A player will win by means of expansionary, militaristic, diplomatic, or scientific policies. The game features great details of empire building and fleet management.

"Who was blinded on the road to Damascus?" "Who asked to be tried in Rome?" Players answer these and other questions from the book of Acts as they match these four-sided dominoes. There are two complete sets of dominoes with one set emphasizing people, and the other set emphasizing places. Scriptural references and an answer key is included. 2-4 players. Ages 10 and up

This game reinforces the proper use of grammar as players identify and correct common grammatical errors. Over 700 sentences at three levels of difficulty are included. Throughout the game there are mistakes that are commonly made in the usage of adjectives, adverbs, questions, verbs, subject verb agreement, nouns, comparisons, superlatives, gerunds, infinitives, prepositions and more. A comprehensive answer key is included. Great for all English Language Learners (ESL) low intermediate to advanced and English grades 6-12.

item.description: Bible Search is a game of advance and block whose moves are generated by correctly answering the questions, of which there are 3 categories (Beginner, Intermediate and Advanced) in each of 2 sources, the Old Testament and the New Testament. Correctly answering a question generates 2 choices, a move to advance your pawn 1 space, or a block option which, if successful, allows you to block your opponent(s) progress, or chance missing a turn, advancing 2 spaces or moving back 2 if question incorrectly answered or advancing 1 space or moving back 2 if question incorrectly answered.

With 42 wooden rods ( six color groups of seven rods each) you should try to build as high a tower as possible. The color die decides if you have to put new rods on top of the tower or if you can pass the die to the next player without adding rods.

The game starts with 2 different colored rods placed parallel on the playing surface.

The first player rolls the die, if rolls the same color as one of the rods on top of the tower, he can pass the die to the next player.

If he rolls a different color as one of the two rods on top of the tower, he must place to new, differently colored, rods on top of the tower. These have to be placed at a right angle to the others.

You continue to play like this clockwise in turn.

The game is over when the tower collapses. The player who caused the crash loses the game.

name.value: Capes & Cowls: The Superhero Board Game
Capes & Cowls: Adventures in Wyrd City

item.description:
From demo packet:

Capes & Cowls: Adventures in Wyrd City. It's super fun in 3 easy steps:


 1. Recruit a team of heroes. 
 2. Send them into battle. 
 3. Clobber till content.


Wyrd City—where conflict lies in wait around every corner and the shadows are acrawl with mystery and adventure, where liberty wanes, government waxes, and a chosen few don capes and cowls to take their stand in a world gone Wyrd....

Capes & Cowls: The Superhero Board Game features 32 original Heroes (and/or villains, depending on your perspective) and several Crews of secondary characters, including Freedom Patrols, Liberty Bots, Diabloids, Arachnidrones, Darklings, thugs, and zombies. Each Hero is defined by personalized stats (Attack, Defense, Speed, and Vigor) and 3 unique Powers, while each Crew is defined by personalized stats and 1 unique Power. Altogether, Capes & Cowls provides over 75 characters with over 100 Powers.
 
Capes & Cowls is played on a unique Battleboard whose color- and number-coded spaces influence character abilities, modify power levels, and place strong emphasis on strategic and tactical play. Though certain game situations do require a roll of the Battle Die, skillful players will find themselves seldom relying on luck to determine the outcome of an action. In short, the player who recruits and manages his team of Heroes most wisely will nearly always prove the victor.

Capes & Cowls offers the following 3 modes of play:

1. Basic: In the Basic Game, each player recruits a team of 2 or 3 Heroes, deploys the team to the Battleboard, and dukes it out with his opponent’s team for a predetermined number of rounds. The victory goes to the player with the most Heroes left on the Battleboard at the end of the game.

2. Standard: The Standard Game allows each player to recruit a team of 4 or 5 Heroes, and introduces Scene Features such as Rooftops, Walls, and Trees, as well as Objects such as Boulders, Cars, and Mailboxes. These elements enrich the Battleboard environment and call for keener strategies and sharper tactics. The victory, as in the Basic Game, goes to the player with the most Heroes left on the Battleboard at the end of the game.

3. Adventure: The Adventure Game requires the players to select an Adventure from the Adventure Book. Each Adventure includes a full-color map for Battleboard setup, instructions for team recruitment, and special rules for playing the chosen Adventure, including team-specific goals and victory conditions. This mode of play incorporates Crew characters, special items, and plot devices that further define the Wyrd City universe and its colorful assortment of costumed denizens. The victory in an Adventure Game goes to the player whose team succeeds in fulfilling the predetermined goal of the Adventure.

In addition to the above modes of play, Capes & Cowls also allows for solitaire and multiplayer variations.

Wyrd City—where the “good guys” are bad, the “bad guys” are you, and the dress code is decidedly unusual.

Capes & Cowls: The Superhero Board Game! Let the battle begin!

item.description:
From the English instructions of play.

“The conquest of the west” reproduces the phases through which the colonists had to go, being first obliged to obtain their “traveling equipment” and then to set of into the unknown west. 
This game does not belong to any specific time in XIX century and so people and historic events that really took place on different dates appear at same time.

From two to six players can take part, the winner being the one who first reached the points with a red circle inside, situated on the pacific coast.
First of all, each player must obtain this “traveling equipment” consisting of oxen, arms, provisions, and a wagon in the east, that is, on the green section of the board; then having acquired his equipment, the player enters the red section, which is the west, in order to attain his objective

NAC edition 1982
Factor Games edition 1990

Corsair Leader is based on the Hornet Leader II core game, but with some significant changes. The game focuses on the Marine F4U Corsairs in the Pacific. The 2 campaigns cover the Solomon Islands campaign that lasted from late 1942 to early 1944.

Also, the aircraft under your command center on the Corsair, but you also get to decide if you want to include Dauntlesses, B-25s, and B-17s as part of your group. Each aircraft has its own advantages and disadvantages. For example, the B-17s carry a lot of bombs and are hard to shoot down, but they are terrible versus naval targets and only moderately accurate against all but the largest of land targets.

The game also goes more in-depth on the tactical options you have while over target. Each turn, each aircraft can become "Offensive" which gives it an attack bonus, but also makes it easier to be attacked when it gets shot at. Likewise, aircraft can be "Defensive" which penalizes their own attacks and makes them harder to hit. "Slow" pilots can "Rush" their attack at a penalty and attack during the Fast pilot step, and "Fast" pilots can Wait and get a bonus if they attack during the Slow pilot step.

Like the other games in the "Leader" series, Corsair Leader is a solitaire game.

The game is published in both PDF and Vassal versions.

Other Leader series games by Dan Verssen

name.value: Galli Galli Sim Sim Rummy for Kids

item.description:
This is a good introductory rummy game for children. The game is for ages 3+ and is for 2-4 players. There is a game board that has four toy story characters with numbers 1-6. The idea of the game is to be the player with the most set tokens once the game board is filled.

The game board is filled by either laying a set 3 tiles of same suit in sequence (1, 2, 3 of Woody) or 3 tiles of the same number (4 woody, 4 buzz, 4 what's the horses name again). You can also add to a set.

There is a wild card in Zurg and there are bonus plays with him.

The Sesame Street version is effectively the same game with a different character-set.

Scale is 240 yards per hex and each unit is a battalion or regiment. There are also some German companies for the front trenches. There are two 13x19" maps with over 200 counters. There are two rules books - standard rules that are 5 pages and Messines:1917 rules that run another 4 pages. There are two scenarios - first day and campaign. Artillery is the centerpiece of the game with four different types of bombardment (saturation, standard, intermittent, and gas) possible. There are three types of guns - field, medium, and heavy with each best suited to certain roles. For Messines the addition of mines makes initial set up and play a real chess match. The key to victory is correct deployment and effective use of reserves. For the Allies, one of the key decisions is how much to bombard. It is very effective but it also destroys the drainage systems of the area and leads to a quagmire that with eliminated possibilities. For the German player, commitment of reserves is the key. He has to guess correctly at the main points of attack by the British player before they have sufficiently evolved to make the attack plan apparent.

item.description: This trick-taking game is played with a standard deck of playing cards. Each game, a pair of dice is rolled. The first die determines how many cards are held in each player's hand (1-6); the other die is special and determines the trump suit. The second die may come up "no trump" (there is no trump suit) or "no suit" (suit doesn't matter, only face value). Chips are used to keep score. Players must ante up before each hand, and the pot is won by the first player to reach eleven points (or to have the highest score after four hands). Scoring centers around the fact that at start of each game, players use bidding wheels to predict how many hands they can win. Penalties are applied for guessing incorrectly, while guessing correctly and winning all tricks in a hand can lead to an instant win.

Good stewardship of time, ability, and money is an important part of life. This exciting game introduces children to the principles of good stewardship. As players move around the game board they earn money for a variety of tasks. They learn to put money in savings and in the church offering. There are opportunities to spend money, recycle and do community service projects. A scripture memory component is also included. For 2-4 players. Ages 6 - 12

Your Number's Up is a fast-paced game for 2 to 6 players. The object of the game is to score as many points as possible, by completing simple sums. The first player lays a number card down and subsequent players have to complete the sum. The player completing the sum takes the three cards as their trick and starts the next round. Sounds easy? Well maybe! What happens if you cannot complete the sum? You have to pick up a spare card and wait for your next turn. This game can be played by people with all levels of ability and in our testing, we found some people with devious minds who tried to stop others winning tricks. I'm sure you wouldn't do this! It's fun, but make sure number isn't up by having a handful of cards at the end.

name.value: Diez juegos que no se parecen a nada

item.description:
This book contains nine new card games mostly played with a regular deck. Some of these games were also published separately.


 Babel - A real time party game that simulates the stock market. This can play a large number of people as long as you have enough card decks to pull it off (1/3 the number of players)



 Leopard - A card game that allows you to sabotage your opponent.



 Auction - An auction game where the playing cards are money.



 Variety - A game that uses bidding to counteract the possibility of getting a bad hand.



 Metamorphosis - A trick taking game where the rules change each hand.



 Switch - A partnership game where the partners switch every hand.



 Eleusis - An induction game.



 Construction - A board game where the board is built with cards.



 Ultima - A fast action chess variant.

Here's a great card game for visual learners! Players match equivalent fractions or find sums of "ONE." Included are cards representing halves, thirds, fourths, sixths, and eighths. Each card pictures a fraction, gives the number word, and shows its corresponding numeral.
Eleven games are included in this domino game. It's a great activity for individual drill on addition and multiplication, or it can be used in a small group in a learning center.
Here's a great way to learn about percentages using dominoes! It's a great game for individuals, or small groups in a learning center.
Subtraction Dominoes provide a unique way to learn subtraction facts with differences from 1 to 18. It's a great learning tool for individual or small group us in a learning center environment.

Battle of the Monsters is a set of several games that can be played using the trading cards included in the Weird n' Wild Creatures collectors set. Weird n' Wild Creatures is a set of colorful data cards covering monsters of nature and mythology. The creatures on the data cards are also depicted on trading cards which list values for attack, defense, and life, which are used to play the Battle of the Monsters games. Some cards also list special powers. The games that can be played with the cards range from the very simple (a war variant where cards and drawn and attack values are compared) to the strategic.

item.description:
From the tube...
".. a game which truly simulates real harness racing. You control your horse's speed, decide when to make your move and make all of the other decisions. Your driving skill - not just luck - determines the outcome." The object is to drive your horse the farthest twice around the track.

Yes the game is packaged in a tube. The "board" is a piece of fabric backed printed vinyl, similar to a place mat. Players are assigned or pick a horse from a choice of 200 in the Stable book. Each horse has a movement number that is broken down into quarters (4 numbers), one for each quarter mile (track is a half mile). These quarter mile numbers are then reduced to 6 numbers, from 1 to 9. These 6 numbers are printed on cards. On his turn the player uses one card to move his horse. The move is modified by: spaces that count as two, variable length lanes in the curves, swaping cards with the draw pile without changing the movement #, holding back a card till the next quarter mile, blocking another from holding back a card, chance cards at the start and on the home stretch, chance dice roll is required to pass thru a space directly in front of another horse. It is recommended to have a race secretary. This person should be a fair minded person who will set up and referee the race.

The players try to use all of their movement while causing others to waste movement. This player has observed that it is easy for all of the players to use all of their movement with only 6 horses in the race. All of the movement robbing mechanisms are easily avoided with 6 horses. The race is then determined by the movement number combined with the Start and Stretch chance cards. The use of 12 horses makes a much more interesting game. With 12 horses the movement robbing mechanisms can not be totally avoided.

John Campbell is a Hall of Fame driver (not rider) that holds many of the sport's records. John Campbell did not design the game but has endorsed it. The 1989 instructions invite players to a yearly tournament where the championship is decided by playing against John Campbell.

The instructions promote another game, "Classic Thoroughbred Racing" which is not currently in the BGG database.

item.description: Here's a basic addition activity using a competitive tic-tac-toe format. Three levels of difficulty cover addition problems from 1 to 20. Great for home use or in learning centers.
Here's a basic subtraction activity using a competitive tic-tac-toe format. Three levels of difficulty cover subtraction problems from 1 to 20. Great for home use or in learning centers.
Here's a basic multiplication activity using a competitive tic-tac-toe format. Three levels of difficulty cover basic multiplication problems. Great for home use or in learning centers.
Here's a basic division activity using a competitive tic-tac-toe format. Three levels of difficulty cover basic division problems. Great for home use or in learning centers.

This exciting game sharpens player's addition and subtraction skills as they capture spaces on the board by adding together numerals printed on color-coded disks. Strategy is used to capture other players spaces by exchanging disks on their own space or on an opponent's space. The winner is the player who is the first to capture four squares in one row, one column or one diagonal. Great for two players or teams. Grades 2-8

A nautical quiz game where navigators must sail the seas and answer questions about ecology and the rules of the sea.

Themed on the show of the same name on France 3.

Strudel (Eddies) is essentially Parchisi in reverse; players try not to be the first to lose all four pieces to the eddies. Every turn, players roll two dice, advance any pieces from their start area if possible, and then use any remaining dice to move their own pieces or even whole rings of currents.
The sneaky bats have escaped! Fly to their rescue with Mother Bat and bring them back to the cave! With luck and skill, be the first to catch four bats!

Is Buxtehude West or East of Hamburg? And where is Kassel? In the North, or in the South? Those who know a little about Germany won’t have any trouble placing the location cards in their correct places. And those who don’t will certainly learn a thing or two when playing Ausgerechnet Buxtehude (It had to be Buxtehude). Because really, it’s not so much about putting the cards in the right spots – it’s more about making the other players believe they’re right. But if a falsely-played card is called out, trouble follows...

item.description: Competition and strategy makes this game fun and exciting. Players learn to build words by connecting prefix, suffix, and base words. It's great for two players or two teams. Grades 4-8

The board displays a rainbow with 6 colored tracks. The player pawns are animals. Each animal carries a jewel on its back.
At each turn the player throws a die and moves his/her pawn. A player may move forward or sideways. If the jewel on the back of the animal corresponds with the course of the rainbow, the animal moves faster. Otherwise the animal moves slower.
The first player with all of his/her animals at the other end of the rainbow wins the game.

From the game's website (www.mauerfall89.de):
"Mauerfall 89" is a game with a political background which tries to focus the oblivion of the GDR (former eastern Germany). It deals with the fall of the Berliner wall in 1989. Goal of the game is the fall of the wall (respectively game stones) with demonstrations and attempts to escape - but the regime doesn't sleep...

"Mauerfall 89" was released in 2005 as a limited first edition.

name.value: Hermann und Thusnelda verprügeln die Römer
Hermann and Thusnelda beat up the Romans

item.description:
From the publisher website:
Hermann und Thusnelda verprügeln die Römer (Hermann and Thusnelda beat up the Romans) deals with the Varus battle in the year 9 AD. In contrast to reality in the game the Romans has a real chance to win...
By request the game rules will also be in Latin!

This game is positioned as a family game it allows players to portray police detectives investigating the robbery or thieves who steal art. The game includes 36 cards that teach the players about different artwork.

The game is inspired by the theft of Munch's Scream, because of this the game has stirred some controversy

"The fast game for long flanks, ideal passing and tactical moves."

A simple abstract strategy game of soccer with four players per side. Released in 2005 at Essen. I'm not positive about the actual name of the publisher.

A dice driven soccer game where the rolls move your teammates into the best positions to score. "The teams are on the pitch and soon the finale will start. Which trainer will be the most successful in getting their players into good positions".

Players alternate rolling a die and moving a player with the appropriate number. A goal is scored if you move one of your players into an opponent goal. Alternatively you can score by blocking your opponent from moving.

Actions are based more on abstract strategy rather than soccer mechanics.

item.description:
"Become a general in the Napoleonic Period and challenge a friend on the battlefield. Charge! is a non-collectible card game for 2 players. With Charge! you can revive the emotion of leading an Army and win a battle. Dispatch your orders to your infantry regiments, fire at the enemy army with your cannons and force it to retreat with your cavalry charges."

A card war game involving advancing your units to break the line of your opponent. Debuted at Essen 05.

"Mum and daddy are gone, the house is quiet and tidy... for now."

"Start a frantic household warfare with other babies. Look for the most useful items in the rooms and make the worse mess possible. Put on your leather jacket, arm yourself with the frying pan and try stirring the pot, go on the skateboard to move faster. Put the stereo at full volume, flood the bathroom and make the babysitter run away. You have to prove to everybody who is the Bad Baby of the house. But be aware that nobody can see you cry or wet the bed... or your reputation will be seriously compromised."

A non-collectible card game with 132 cards (including 8 Baby cards, 15 Kitchen cards, 15 Living Room cards, 15 Bedroom cards, 15 Bathroom cards, 36 Action cards, 12 Event cards and 16 Baby Power cards), 4 Room boards, 16 Furniture tokens, and 8 Baby tokens. (Note: The game's manual says 18 Event cards, but this was a misprint.)

item.description:
From the designers' website:

"From nobody to little fish to bootlegger to capo di tuti capi...

King of Chicago is a board game about building the strongest gangster empire of 1920s Chicago. It's a strategy game with ample opportunities for politics, alliances, betrayal, and luck.

Each player gains strength and power through building illegal businesses and hiring handpicked mobsters to his gang. In bullet rains from drive by shootings, raids, and corrupt police, historic Chicago becomes the perfect setting for this action packed board game.

King of Chicago is for 2 - 6 players Ages 14 and up The game appeals to fans of classics such as Risk, Axis and Allies and Illuminati. It's an intensive game for younger players, and an intelligent challenge for more experienced board game enthusiasts."
